author: By Caroline Hopkins Legaspi
title: How Healthy Is Broccoli?
description: The dinnertime standard is a nutritional multitasker.
content: Children may not want to hear this, but broccoli more than deserves its place on our plates. The florets and stems are filled with nutrients that help keep your heart and bones healthy — and may reduce the risk of cancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Taylor Robinson
title: In a Tight Presidential Race, Third-Party Candidates Present a Wild Card
description: In every battleground state this year, there is at least one third-party or independent candidate on the ballot. The Democrats have been more openly concerned than Republicans.
content: With a month to go before what is widely expected to be an extraordinarily close election, an extra element of unpredictability looms: In every battleground state, there is at least one third-party or independent presidential candidate on the ballot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Reporter’s Shield Law Is Vital to Prevent Abuses of Power
description: The PRESS Act has unanimous support in the House, but a few senators are blocking it.
content: Governments often chafe at the presence of a free press. The reason is simple: A robust and independent news media keeps a sharp eye on government and, when necessary, exposes abuse of power, corruption, incompetence and waste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: A Hezbollah attack on an Israeli military base.
content: A drone strike by Hezbollah on a base in northern Israel killed four soldiers and wounded dozens of other people, the Israeli military said yesterday, in what some saw as evidence of a worrisome gap in Israel’s air defense systems. Cross-border attacks by the militants have continued despite heavy Israeli bombardments aimed at Hezbollah targets in Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A 1924 Spanish Revival house in Los Angeles, a 1962 midcentury-modern house in San Rafael, and a recently remodeled 1916 house in Oakland.
content: This four-bedroom, three-bath house is in the Lafayette Square Historic Protection Overlay Zone, a semi-gated neighborhood in central Los Angeles recognized for its well-kept, stately homes showcasing popular architectural styles of the 1920s and 1930s. On this block are a mix of Tudor-revival, Mediterranean-revival and Spanish-revival homes. Public elementary and middle schools are nearby, as is a branch of the Los Angeles Public Library.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Tuesday Briefing: India Accused of Homicide and Extortion
description: Plus, an artist sues to reclaim his work.
content: Canada accused the Indian government yesterday of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada. Canada also expelled Sanjay Kumar Verma, India’s top diplomat, and five others, saying they were part of a vast criminal network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, Eric Lipton, Olivia Natt, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Nina Feldman, Stella Tan, Rikki Novetsky, Michael Benoist, Marc Georges, Chris Haxel, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: Inside an Unprepared Secret Service
description: The protection agency is facing questions after two assassination attempts on former President Donald J. Trump.
content: After the assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump in Butler, Pa., Congress held hearings on the failures of the Secret Service, and its director, Kimberly Cheatle, stepped down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaleigh Rogers
title: Where Polls Can Mess Up (and What Pollsters Do About It)
description: Conducting a poll isn’t an exact science. The process is susceptible to lots of common problems and baked-in biases — more than just the “margin of error.”
content: With less than a month until Election Day, you may be paying more attention to political polls, and starting to wonder how much you ought to trust them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italian Court Overturns Women’s Acquittals in ‘Bunga Bunga’ Legal Saga
description: The ruling sets the stage for yet another trial related to the scandal involving Silvio Berlusconi, the former prime minister of Italy who died last year.
content: After 14 years, the 21 women accused of helping to cover up Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s evening bacchanals had hoped that their long legal saga over the so-called “Bunga Bunga” scandal might be over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Man Is Arrested on Weapons Charges Heading to Trump Rally in Coachella, Officials Say
description: Law-enforcement officials said that former President Donald J. Trump was not in any danger, and the man was released on bail.
content: A man was arrested and accused of illegal weapons possession as he was trying to enter former President Donald J. Trump’s rally in Coachella, Calif., on Saturday evening, the Riverside County sheriff’s office said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Will Leopard Print Ever Go Out of Style?
description: A reader is puzzled by the popularity of animal print in women’s fashion. Our critic offers an explanation for its appeal.
content: Leopard print — indeed, all animal prints, including zebra, python, cow and many not actually found in nature — have been with us since our long-ago ancestors turned the pelts of the animals they killed for food into clothing. Its role as a signifier has changed according to time and context, but it has never really disappeared, even as fur itself has fallen out of favor. While the lion may be king of the jungle, the leopard, or at least the leopard’s spots, is the king of fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Russia’s Latest Target in Africa: U.S.-Funded Anti-Malaria Programs
description: Scientists fighting the spread of infectious diseases on the continent have been targeted online by pro-Russian activists, part of an effort to spread fear and mistrust of the West.
content: The scientists sifting through thousands of genetically modified mosquito larvae in a laboratory in Burkina Faso were trying to stop the spread of malaria, one of the biggest killers on the African continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reeves Wiedeman
title: A Fact Checker Reflects on Our Age of Political Lying
description: In “Beyond the Big Lie,” Bill Adair worries that the world of spin and fabrication in America has gotten out of hand.
content: In 2002, Bill Adair, who was then a political reporter for The St. Petersburg Times, took note of a new neighbor on his block in Arlington, Va. Mike Pence had recently become a congressman, and moved in four doors down. Their families became fast friends, and Adair came to respect Pence, especially as a politician willing to live in hostile territory: Pretty much everyone else on the block was a Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Italy Sends Boat to Albania With Migrants Who Were Bound for Italian Shores
description: The plan was heralded by the Italian government as an innovative model to manage and deter immigration, and criticized by human rights groups.
content: Italy sent its first boat carrying migrants to Albania on Monday, part of a plan to send migrants who are rescued in the Mediterranean by Italian ships to detention centers in the Balkan nation, where their asylum claims will be assessed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Canada Expels Indian Diplomats, Accusing Them of Criminal Campaign
description: The Canadian police said the Indian government had orchestrated homicides and extortion in Canada to intimidate Sikh separatists. India, in return, kicked out Canadian diplomats.
content: Canada accused the Indian government on Monday of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada, escalating a bitter dispute that began last year with an assassination of a Sikh activist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Selig
title: Meteorologists Face Harassment and Death Threats Amid Hurricane Disinformation
description: Weather experts say the spiraling falsehoods, especially claims that the government is creating or controlling storms, have gotten out of hand.
content: A meteorologist based in Washington, D.C., was accused of helping the government cover up manipulating a hurricane. In Houston, a forecaster was repeatedly told to “do research” into the weather’s supposed nefarious origins. And a meteorologist for a television station in Lansing, Mich., said she had received death threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: N.J. Transit Train Hits Tree on Track, Killing 1 and Injuring 23
description: A light rail train traveling south from Trenton collided with a chunk of tree, killing the train’s operator.
content: One person was killed and nearly two dozen others were injured in South Jersey on Monday morning when a New Jersey Transit light rail train struck a tree on the tracks, the commuter rail said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French and Sophia Alvarez Boyd
title: America Needs More Children. JD Vance’s Shame Game Won’t Get Us There.
description: David French argues the solution is simpler than we think.
content: Despite concerns over the falling birthrate, especially on the right, the Times Opinion columnist David French recognizes that the push to have more families — and bigger ones — has become problematic. In this audio essay, French explains why he thinks the recent political conversation on the topic reveals “the worst form of natalism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Kamala Harris Sets an Interview With a Not-So-Friendly Outlet: Fox News.
description: The interview, to be conducted by the anchor Bret Baier in Pennsylvania, will air Wednesday at 6 p.m. Eastern.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has agreed to an interview with Fox News, the network said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Russia Is Clawing Back Land Taken by Ukraine This Summer
description: Moscow’s forces have been recapturing some villages and land taken in a Ukrainian incursion into Russia. The advances could undermine Kyiv’s hopes of pushing Russia to the negotiating table.
content: Russia has recaptured a few villages in its western borderlands that Ukraine invaded over the summer, threatening Kyiv’s hold on territory it views as crucial leverage for pushing Moscow toward negotiations to end the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohammed Aghaalkurdi
title: Polio Threatens Gaza Today. Tomorrow, It Could Be Cholera.
description: The success of the polio vaccination campaign in Gaza shouldn’t obfuscate the threat of other diseases.
content: In August, health officials recorded the first case of polio in Gaza in more than 25 years, in an unvaccinated 10-month-old baby whose lower left leg became paralyzed by the virus. Sadness and frustration washed over me when I first heard the news. It is outrageous that polio — which is highly contagious and can cause paralysis, respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse and even death — has been permitted to reappear in Gaza after being nearly eradicated across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Sam Bush
title: Amid a Water Crisis, England Asks: Who Should Be in Charge?
description: Four decades after privatization, calls to nationalize the water industry have swept across England and Wales amid sewage spills and rising household bills.
content: On its journey to the North Sea, the River Thames runs through Henley, a picturesque middle-class town about 35 miles west of London. The river is central to the town’s identity, which is known for its annual royal regatta and for being the location of the first boat race between Oxford and Cambridge Universities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Bittman
title: Food Is What We Have In Common. Why Don’t We Hear More From the Candidates About It?
description: Food is the springboard to talk about a host of issues, including climate, economic justice, public health and labor.
content: In a surprising turn of events, the presidential candidates have been talking about food. Food can be a winning topic, but we need to hear much more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Political Misdiagnosis
description: Democrats imagined that they would become the majority party as America became more racially diverse. It’s not working out that way.
content: The Democratic Party has spent years hoping that demography would equal destiny. As the country became more racially diverse, Democrats imagined that they would become the majority party thanks to support from Asian, Black and Hispanic voters. The politics of America, according to this vision, would start to resemble the liberal politics of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya C. Miller
title: Michigan Republican Blames ‘Proofing Error’ for Misleading Ad in Black-Owned Newspaper
description: The state’s legislative Black caucus has asked the attorney general and a county prosecutor to investigate Tom Barrett’s congressional campaign for potential voter disenfranchisement.
content: Black state lawmakers in Michigan are calling on the state’s attorney general and a local county prosecutor to investigate the congressional campaign of Tom Barrett, a Republican, for an ad in a Black-owned newspaper that incorrectly listed Election Day as Nov. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson and Amy Chang Chien
title: China Holds War Games Encircling Taiwan in Warning to Island’s Leader
description: Scores of Chinese aircraft and dozens of ships surrounded Taiwan, after President Lai Ching-te rejected Beijing’s claim over the island.
content: China held large-scale military drills in the waters and skies surrounding Taiwan on Monday, a show of force that signaled the growing threat of Beijing’s ability to choke the self-governing island that China claims as its own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Wranglers’ and ‘Elsbeth’
description: A CW documentary, inspired by the series “Yellowstone,” shows what real life in ranch country looks like. And “The Good Wife” spinoff is back for a second season.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, Oct. 14-20 Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Has Become Unmoored in Time
description: His grim vision of America seems stuck in the past.
content: This is the second in an occasional series about Donald Trump’s statements and language and what’s at stake in the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: An Artist Signed Over His Career to Investors. Now He Wants It Back.
description: Bjarne Melgaard’s rise in the art world came with strings attached and an unusual contract with investors. Now he’s suing to regain control of his artwork.
content: The “Main Agreement” was supposed to be the final agreement, a contract to end all other contracts between two investors and Bjarne Melgaard, a provocative Norwegian artist who had drawn notice at the 2011 Venice Biennale with an exhibition about a fictional movement of gay terrorists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Howard, Christopher Flavelle and Caitlin Ochs
title: How Climate Disasters Are Making Mobile Homes a Huge Risk
description: Millions of Americans, many poor and vulnerable, live in mobile and manufactured homes. When catastrophe strikes, they’re often on their own.
content: By the time the murky brown water in the house reached his chest, Joe Rogers realized it was too late to leave safely. Then, in an instant, his mobile home shifted violently, creating a wave that swept up furniture and trapped his wife, Sandra, in their bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rose Courteau
title: A Painter With an Eye for the Ridiculous
description: The artist Ambera Wellmann’s work explores sex and climate change, while incorporating mermaids, tarot cards and memes.
content: When the Canadian artist Ambera Wellmann painted “Strobe” (2021), a Surrealist beach landscape measuring 30 feet in length, she had just moved to New York, where she’d found representation with Company Gallery. Before that, she’d produced relatively small works, but now she was thinking big. “New York loves sensationalism in a way that’s kind of refreshing,” she says. “People like to make a splash.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Russian Oil Flows Through Western ‘Price Cap’ as Shadow Fleet Grows
description: A report shows how Russia has largely evaded sanctions aimed at limiting its revenue from oil sales.
content: A plan hatched by wealthy Western nations to deprive Russia of oil revenue is largely faltering, a new report found, with the majority of the Kremlin’s seaborne oil exports evading restrictions that were supposed to limit the price of Russian crude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Growing Darkness, October Light: A Backyard Census
description: I wish you could see what happens to the magnificent colors of berry and bird and flower in the slanting autumn light.
content: There’s hardly a spot of color on the hardwood trees in our yard, but the light is glorious, as it always is in October, and the signs of fall are unmistakable. The pokeweed, in full berry-laden splendor at the end of September, has been reduced to drooping leaves and magenta stems. Likewise the beautyberry and arrowwood shrubs, each picked down to the woody stems by cardinals and blue jays and mockingbirds and all manner of other creatures in this small, teeming yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul, Vimal Patel and Dylan Freedman
title: Conservative Activist Seizes on Passages From Harris Book
description: A report by Christopher Rufo says the Democratic presidential nominee copied five short passages for her 2009 book on crime. A plagiarism expert said the lapses were not serious.
content: The conservative activist Christopher Rufo published claims on Monday that Vice President Kamala Harris had copied portions of her 2009 book “Smart on Crime,” citing five sections that he said were lifted from widely available sites including Wikipedia and news reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rush Doshi
title: What China’s Leaders Grasp About Another Trump Term
description: Trump remains well outside a bipartisan consensus on competing with China.
content: At the beginning of the Biden presidency, many of us serving in the National Security Council gathered to read the intelligence and reached a key conclusion: The 2020s would be what we called the “decisive decade” in U.S. competition with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Can Wall St. Help Harris Win Pennsylvania?
description: The vice president has raised huge sums and has won over many business leaders. Despite that, the presidential race remains tight in battleground states.
content: Despite entering the presidential contest only about three months ago, Vice President Kamala Harris has shattered fund-raising expectations — in large part because she has managed to win over many of the business donors who had been lukewarm about President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Can Charlotte, N.C., Deliver for Kamala Harris?
description: Mecklenburg County leans liberal but has broken Democrats’ hearts in past elections with low voter turnout. A new party leader wants to change that.
content: When Democrats try to explain why their party has lost every presidential and Senate race in North Carolina since 2008, they often point to an unexpected place: Mecklenburg County, which includes the deep-blue city of Charlotte.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Attention Kmart Shoppers: It’s Closing Time
description: As the last full-size Kmart in the continental United States prepares to close, shoppers reminisced about the store that once sold everything, everywhere.
content: When Chrissy Economos and Gloria McCourtney heard that the last full-size Kmart in the mainland United States was closing down, they knew they had to pay their respects, even if the store was more than 1,300 miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Three Weeks to Go, and That’s All Anyone Is Sure Of
description: It’s been a long year. That won’t stop it from being a very long 22 days.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, Kamala Harris sure seems proud of her gun ownership, doesn’t she?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: In Jordan, a ‘Stunning’ Discovery Under Petra’s Ancient Stone
description: A recent excavation has unearthed 12 human skeletons and a chamber of grave offerings near Petra’s Treasury building, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
content: By the time Dr. Richard Bates swept his radar device over the sandstone of Petra’s ancient Treasury building, it had been more than two decades since anyone had so deeply probed the stone city’s grounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Gallagher, Brett Anderson, Melissa Clark and Nikita Richardson
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Portland, Ore., Right Now
description: The dining capital of the Pacific Northwest remains one of America’s great culinary cities.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Trump and Harris Both Like a Child Tax Credit, but With Different Aims
description: Kamala Harris’s campaign is pushing a version of the credit intended to fight child poverty, while Donald J. Trump sees the program primarily as a tax cut for people higher up the income scale.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has made an expanded child tax credit central to her campaign, and former President Donald J. Trump boasts, “I doubled the child tax credit.” With a quick look, voters might think the child-rearing subsidy the rare matter on which the rival candidates agree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 492
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: York Theater Artistic Director Out After ‘Hurtful’ Diversity Comments
description: James Morgan, who has been with the small New York theater company for 50 years, blamed the effects of a stroke for his behavior.
content: The longtime leader of the York Theater Company, a small New York nonprofit known for its emphasis on musical theater, is acknowledging making “hurtful” comments about diversity that he says prompted his abrupt departure from the organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn and Chad Unger
title: American Sign Language Brings New Layers to ‘American Idiot’
description: Performed simultaneously in sign language and sung English, a Los Angeles revival of the Green Day musical finds new ways to communicate rage and angst.
content: Inside the Mark Taper Forum in downtown Los Angeles on a recent Wednesday, the air was saturated with stage fog and preshow jitters. The first performance of a revival of Green Day’s “American Idiot” was just hours away, and the choreographer Jennifer Weber had some final instructions for the cast members, who were wearing their costumes — combat boots, eyeliner, enough artfully ripped jeans to fill a Hot Topic — while they ran through dance movements onstage. Weber, microphone in hand, sang the song “Homecoming” as she demonstrated choreography:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: Kash Patel: The Magical Rise of a Self-Described ‘Wizard’ in Trump World
description: The MAGA loyalist Mr. Patel aims to run the C.I.A. if Donald Trump wins the presidency. But critics say his swagger masks deep inexperience.
content: As President Donald J. Trump battled public outrage in the summer of 2019 over his effort to enlist Ukraine in digging up dirt on former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., he summoned a small group of top advisers to the Oval Office. Among them was Charles Kupperman, the deputy national security adviser, who was surprised to see a relatively low-level staff member in one of the four chairs arrayed before the president’s desk: Kashyap “Kash” Patel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Jennifer Medina, Megha Rajagopalan, Robert Jimison and Jessica Metzger
title: U.S. to Send Troops to Israel, and a Splintering Democratic Coalition
description: Plus, SpaceX makes a tricky “catch.”
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: What is the THAAD Antimissile System the U.S. Is Giving to Israel?
description: It can intercept missiles above earth’s atmosphere, and is being deployed to defend against Iranian attacks.
content: The advanced THAAD air defense system that the United States is sending to Israel is a sign of how both countries are bracing for more attacks against Israel by Iran and its allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Eric Lipton
title: Another Trump Clemency Recipient Faces Domestic Violence-Related Charges
description: Philip Esformes is at least the seventh person to be charged with new crimes after receiving a second chance in the last days of the Trump administration.
content: A Florida man who received a commutation of a 20-year fraud sentence from President Donald J. Trump in 2020 — only to plead guilty this year to a related crime — was arrested on Sunday on domestic violence-related charges in South Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Gabby Sobelman
title: Deadly Hezbollah Strike on Army Base Shows Israel’s Weakness Against Drones
description: Israel has one of the world’s best defenses against missiles and rockets, but struggles to detect slower-moving unmanned aircraft, experts said.
content: Minutes before a deadly Hezbollah drone strike on an army base in northern Israel this weekend, Israeli police officers notified the Air Force about reports of a suspicious aircraft, the police said. They were told not to worry because the aircraft was Israeli, prompting the officers to close the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: A Harris Ad Uses the Hurricanes to Try to Inflict Damage on Trump
description: Two former homeland security officials under Donald J. Trump describe how he tried to withhold disaster aid from states that he hadn’t won.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris’s campaign began running this 60-second ad called “Safety and Security” on television stations in Georgia and North Carolina on Thursday and has spent about $75,000 to air it so far in markets affected by the recent hurricane, according to AdImpact. The biggest expenditures have been in Charlotte, Raleigh and Asheville, N.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: 50 Years After Killing, a Berlin Court Convicts a Stasi Officer of Murder
description: The court handed down a guilty verdict and a 10-year sentence to a former officer of East Germany’s dreaded secret police, in a case straight out of the Cold War.
content: It was a brutal act from another time, almost another world, when the Cold War was hot and Germany was divided: An officer of East Germany’s feared secret police shot and killed a man trying to cross into the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: The Trump Voters Who Don’t Believe Trump
description: When the former president endorses violence and proposes using the government to attack his enemies, many of his supporters assume it’s just an act.
content: One of the more peculiar aspects of Donald J. Trump’s political appeal is this: A lot of people are happy to vote for him because they simply do not believe he will do many of the things he says he will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Igielnik
title: Most Voters Have Been Offended by Trump. It’s Not Always a Deal Breaker.
description: Voters who said they had been offended by Donald J. Trump, but not recently, supported him by a wide margin.
content: The vast majority of voters across the United States say they have been offended at some point by former President Donald J. Trump. But a sizable number of those voters say that has not stopped them from supporting him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: They Helped Build the Temple. Now, They’re Bringing It to the Screen.
description: Jeroboam Bozeman and Rennie Harris’s careers have wound through street and concert dance. The two shaped the movement in “Once Again (for the Very First Time).”
content: A man is falling from the sky. Even as he plummets, you can tell he’s a dancer: There is grace in the twisting of his wind-buffeted limbs. He lands not with a thud but a whisper, on the tips of his toes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Kornelis
title: Lillian Schwartz, Pioneer in Computer-Generated Art, Dies at 97
description: Early in the digital era, she worked at Bell Labs on the intersection of art and technology, making films and at one point arriving at a novel theory about the “Mona Lisa.”
content: Lillian Schwartz, who was one of the first artists to use the computer to make films and who helped bring together the artistic, scientific and technology communities in the 1970s by providing a glimpse of the possibilities at the intersections of those fields, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Little Bit of Power
description: With enough power to make a small difference, but only that, what do you do?
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: ‘Literally the Quickest Dinner Ever’
description: Yasmin Fahr’s five-star recipe features sweet shrimp, spicy ginger and creamy coconut milk — and has received rave reviews.
content: Of all the frozen proteins you could thaw for an easy weeknight dinner, shrimp are about the speediest and most elegant. Just pour the icy crustaceans into a bowl of cool tap water and let them soften on the counter while you prep the rest of your ingredients. By the time the garlic has been chopped and the spices are lined up on your counter, all the shrimp need is a friendly pat dry with a clean kitchen towel and they’re ready to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: State of the Race: A Close Race Gets Closer
description: There’s no sign that a deluge of surveys from Republican-aligned firms is meaningfully affecting the polling averages.
content: The presidential race just keeps getting tighter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren and Lauren Hirsch
title: How Wall St. Is Subtly Shaping the Harris Economic Agenda
description: The vice president has repeatedly incorporated suggestions from business executives into her economic agenda.
content: When two of Vice President Kamala Harris’s closest advisers arrived in New York last month, they were seeking advice. The Democratic nominee was preparing to give her most far-reaching economic speech, and Tony West, Ms. Harris’s brother-in-law, and Brian Nelson, a longtime confidant, wanted to know how the city’s powerful financiers thought she should approach it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nathaniel Rich
title: The Toxic Sludge That Ate Tennessee
description: The 2008 coal ash spill was among the biggest industrial disasters in U.S. history. In a new book, Jared Sullivan recounts the accident, the lawsuits and the lasting damage.
content: A concise summary of Jared Sullivan’s “Valley So Low” is offered halfway through the book by its hero, Jim Scott, a plain-talking, suspender-wearing, Skittles-addicted plaintiff’s lawyer: “They had a toxic tub of goop, and it blew up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer
title: Why ‘Unbalanced’ Muscles Can Cause You Pain
description: Repeatedly doing the same type of activity — whether it’s running, lifting or sitting — can have serious downsides.
content: When you head out for your daily run, with each stride you’re strengthening your quadriceps, your hamstrings and your upper calf muscles. The muscles on the sides of your hips, however, aren’t growing much.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Regensdorf
title: How to Apply Blush Like a Professional
description: Tips from a “Saturday Night Live” cast member, a ballet dancer and a makeup artist.
content: “Blush is trending,” says the makeup artist Ernesto Casillas, referring to the product’s ongoing popularity on TikTok. “A lot of people are calling it ‘blush blindness’ when someone overapplies it.” For advice on creating a more nuanced look, we turned to three people well attuned to the product’s capabilities: the comedian, actress and “Saturday Night Live” cast member Chloe Fineman, known for her uncanny impressions; the American Ballet Theatre principal dancer James Whiteside, who returns to the stage this month for the company’s fall season; and Casillas, whose clients include the actresses Zendaya and Ayo Edebiri. Here are their tips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Euan Ward and Michael Levenson
title: Tent Camp in Gaza Engulfed by Flames After Israeli Strike
description: At least four Palestinians taking shelter by a hospital were killed in a strike Israeli officials said was targeting a Hamas command center.
content: Israeli strikes in the Gaza Strip killed Palestinians in a tent encampment on the grounds of a hospital and in a school turned shelter, according to residents and U.N. officials, as deadly fighting also raged between Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales and Maya Shwayder
title: Ethel Kennedy, Matriarch of Family Dynasty, Honored at Cape Cod Funeral
description: Several politicians and relatives, including her son Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his wife, the actress Cheryl Hines, were in attendance.
content: About 200 people, along with prominent members of the Kennedy family, crowded into a Catholic church on Cape Cod on Monday for the funeral of Ethel Kennedy, the widow of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and a powerful figure in the family’s political dynasty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,214
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Oct. 15, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: How Door Knocking Is Going in a Wisconsin Swing County
description: Door County, Wis., has picked the presidential winner since 1996. Last time, the margin was 292 votes, so the campaigns are trying to reach every household.
content: Nancy Kidd, a coordinator with the Democratic Party of Door County in northeast Wisconsin, was willing to brave a door-to-door canvass for Democratic votes during a soaking rain in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: They’re ‘Saturday Night Live’ … and You’re Not
description: With so many players involved in Jason Reitman’s new movie about “S.N.L.,” here’s a guide to the real-life personalities.
content: It’s easy to get lost watching “Saturday Night”: Jason Reitman’s new film drops us backstage at a moment of maximum confusion — 90 minutes before the 1975 debut of a new NBC show called “Saturday Night.” At the center of all the hubbub is creator-producer Lorne Michaels (played by Gabriel LaBelle), who’s been the one constant at “S.N.L.” over most of the show’s 50 seasons. But what about all the other characters rushing about, wringing their hands over whether this show will actually make it to air? Here’s a guide:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey and Vincent Alban
title: In Rural Wisconsin, Race Is an Undercurrent of the Presidential Election
description: Former President Donald Trump’s recent attacks on his opponent could affect the vote. “It’s a stirring of the pot,” one voter said.
content: The signs are everywhere that Sauk County, Wis., is a divided place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Learning a Language, and a Few Life Lessons, in France
description: After a painful breakup, the author travels to Provence for a language immersion homestay and learns the value of facing up to mistakes.
content: When I booked a one-on-one intensive language program in France, I envisioned a dreamy getaway, where I could practice French while getting to know Provence through the eyes of a local.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Oct. 14, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 14, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: Killing of Japanese Boy Leaves Chinese Asking: Is This My Country?
description: Angry at what they view as China’s state-led xenophobia, taught in schools and prevalent online, some people are taking action, even at personal risk.
content: A Japanese boy was stabbed on his way to school in China on Sept. 18. That’s the date when, nearly a century earlier in 1931, Japan invaded China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Stock Markets Rebound on Promises to Help Businesses
description: Assurances from government officials on plans to strengthen the private sector offset a lack of specifics about economic stimulus.
content: Stock prices rose in China on Monday, as investors welcomed government signals of renewed attempts to counter weakness in the economy by borrowing more and easing oversight of the private sector.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Armed Man Arrested After Reportedly Threatening FEMA Workers
description: William Jacob Parsons was arrested and charged in North Carolina after he was found with a handgun and a rifle at a supermarket where a federal aid vehicle was parked.
content: A North Carolina man was arrested on Saturday and accused of threatening federal emergency responders who have been administering aid since Hurricane Helene ravaged parts of the state last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bilal Shbair and Erika Solomon
title: Survivors of Gaza Hospital Blaze Say They Are Living a ‘Recurring Nightmare’
description: Scores of families sheltering outside Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital say they have survived a string of Israeli strikes on the compound and feel trapped with nowhere to go.
content: This was not the first time that displaced Gazans camping on the grounds of Al Aqsa Martyrs Hospital awoke to Israeli strikes on the place where they were trying to find safety. But Monday’s strike overshadowed any they had survived before: flames jumping from tent to tent, shrieks of agony and bodies so charred they were unrecognizable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natan Odenheimer, Bilal Shbair and Patrick Kingsley
title: How Israel’s Army Uses Palestinians as Human Shields in Gaza
description: Israeli soldiers and Palestinian former detainees say troops have regularly forced captured Gazans to carry out life-threatening tasks, including inside Hamas tunnels.
content: After Israeli soldiers found Mohammed Shubeir hiding with his family in early March, they detained him for roughly 10 days before releasing him without charge, he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Launches Europa Clipper to Explore an Ocean Moon’s Habitability
description: The spacecraft lifted off Monday on a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket, embarking on a nearly six-year journey to Jupiter.
content: Europa Clipper, the biggest interplanetary spacecraft that NASA has ever built, lifted off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida early Monday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: In Texas, Execution Looms Despite Questions in Shaken Baby Case
description: Robert Roberson could be the first person put to death in connection with shaken baby syndrome. The state’s highest criminal court ruled in another case that the science had changed.
content: Texas is preparing for the execution this week of an autistic man, Robert Roberson, who was convicted of killing his 2-year-old daughter in a case that has drawn intense scrutiny for its reliance on a questionable diagnosis of shaken baby syndrome.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Government Policies to Raise Fertility Rates Haven’t Led to Baby Booms
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 14, 2024.
content: “Living with your mom is not the best romantic environment for finding your lifelong partner.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Fitting In Was Never Randy Newman’s Jam
description: A biography of the singer behind “You’ve Got a Friend in Me” and “Short People” considers a complicated man with a satirical edge.
content: Randy Newman was a nepo baby, a sprig of musical royalty. Three of his uncles were Hollywood film composers. One received 45 Oscar nominations and won nine times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Doctors, A.I. and Empathy for Patients
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about ChatGPT’s bedside manner. Also: Breast cancer screenings; Walz’s missteps; supporting the mental health of schoolchildren.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: America Is on the Brink of a Great Political Realignment. It’s Already Visible in Arizona.
description: He and his acolytes purged the G.O.P. to make it smaller and more strident.
content: One day each month, Charlie Kirk, one of the country’s most influential Republican activists, holds an event called Freedom Night in America at Dream City Church, a Pentecostal megachurch on the outskirts of Phoenix. “I truly believe that God has voted early in this election,” he said on a Wednesday in early October, addressing well over 1,000 people from a stage bathed in red, white and blue lights. “I believe that God voted early on July 13, when he spared the life of Donald Trump.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Three Receive Nobel in Economics for Research on Global Inequality
description: Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson and James Robinson shared the award for their work on explaining the gaps in prosperity between nations.
content: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to Daron Acemoglu and Simon Johnson, both of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and to James Robinson of the University of Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: Why Controlling Blood Sugar Is Crucial for Your Health
description: How often should you test your glucose and A1C? How do food, sleep and exercise affect blood sugar? Here’s what to know.
content: More than one in three adults in the United States has prediabetes, higher-than-normal blood sugar levels that can lead to diabetes. And more than one in 10 has diabetes, characterized by still higher blood sugar levels that can eventually lead to eye problems, heart disease, a stroke, nerve damage and other serious health issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina, Katie Glueck and Ruth Igielnik
title: Harris’s Final Challenge: Restore a Splintering Democratic Coalition
description: Defections from Black and Latino voters are making Kamala Harris more dependent on white, suburban voters — and complicating her path to victory.
content: In the final weeks of the presidential campaign, Vice President Kamala Harris is contending with erosion within the Democratic coalition that put Barack Obama and Joe Biden in the White House, and growing more dependent on white voters who historically aligned more with Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Harris Steps Up a Major Push for Black Voters
description: The vice president released a plan to help Black men financially, held interviews with two Black media outlets and put out targeted ads in battleground states.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris made a sweeping push on Monday to energize Black voters, among whom she faces slipping support, unveiling a plan to bolster the finances of Black men, appearing in interviews with two Black media outlets and releasing a pair of ads in battleground states targeted to that crucial voting group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Ka, Lone Soldier of New York’s Underground Rap Scene, Dies at 52
description: The rapper, whose name was Kaseem Ryan, was known for self-producing 11 albums while also a maintaining a career with the New York Fire Department.
content: Kaseem Ryan, who built a small but fervent following as an underground Brooklyn rapper known as Ka while maintaining a career as a New York City firefighter, died in the city on Saturday. He was 52.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel and Claire Moses
title: Lilly Ledbetter, Whose Fight for Equal Pay Changed U.S. Law, Dies at 86
description: Her lawsuit against Goodyear helped pave the way for the 2009 Fair Pay Act, which was signed into law by former President Barack Obama.
content: Lilly Ledbetter had worked for 19 years at a tire plant in Alabama when she was sent an anonymous note: her pay was as much as $2,000 a month less than what men were receiving in the same supervisory job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Formerly Classified Documents Get the Fine Art Treatment
description: Hundreds of declassified U.S. Army photos are featured in the new book “Fashion Army.”
content: While scouring the internet some years back for obscure images of foods from the 1970s, Matthieu Nicol, a photo researcher in Paris, happened upon a trove of freely available pictures recently declassified by the U.S. Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Guerrero
title: I Froze My Eggs to Reclaim My Right to Rest
description: As a Latina, I was taught that my purpose was to produce. But I needed a break.
content: I watched the ultrasound screen as my OB-GYN counted my follicles, the egg-producing sacs in my ovaries. They looked like the black holes in NASA images. I had more than 30 inside me. The sight unnerved me. My doctor seemed excited. “Those are some juicy-looking ovaries!” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Kassoy
title: OpenAI Could Be a Force for Good if It Can Address These Issues First
description: The artificial intelligence start-up behind ChatGPT needs a legal structure that ensures its commitments can be enforced.
content: OpenAI, the artificial intelligence start-up behind ChatGPT, is now worth as much as Goldman Sachs or AT&T. OpenAI has also said it intends to shed its status as a nonprofit to become a for-profit business within two years. Outside experts and its employees have expressed concern that as a result, the company will shy away from its founding purpose — to build safe A.I. to “benefit all of humanity” — in favor of earning profits for investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: The Wildly Subversive Music of Soviet Ukraine
description: An archival label in the United States was going to release a huge compilation of records from the U.S.S.R. Then Russia invaded Ukraine.
content: Eugene Hutz still owns his copy of “Slayed?,” a 1972 album released the year he was born by the British bad boys Slade that his father purchased on the Ukrainian black market. Its spine is now lined with tape, its cover deeply ringed by the record inside. But for Hutz, 52, it remains a powerful talisman of rock ’n’ roll’s transformative potential, even amid oppressive regimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: In Heated House Race, a Moderate Republican Goes Full Trump
description: Representative Marc Molinaro of New York, running against Josh Riley, a Democrat, has accused recent immigrants of committing violent crimes and killing pets.
content: Representative Marc Molinaro has spent his decades of public service building a reputation as a particular brand of New York Republican: a measured and courteous pragmatist more interested in responsible governing than in ideological battles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marina Harss
title: Isaac Hernández Brings Leading-Man Vibes to Ballet Theater
description: “He has it all,” said Susan Jaffe, the artistic leader of American Ballet Theater. Hernández, already a veteran star, is joining the company as a principal.
content: It was Isaac Hernández’s second week at American Ballet Theater, and he was feeling achy from rehearsals. But as soon as the pianist began to play, his body and eyes snapped to attention. It was his big entrance. He rushed across the studio in series of jumps, legs thwacking together in the air. He turned with one leg extended to the side. He did a circle of leaps that almost brushed the walls. He made the space feel small.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: Here are the records from Miami-Dade jail where Mr. Esformes was held after his arrest.
content: Here are the records from Miami-Dade jail where Mr. Esformes was held after his arrest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By CTV via Reuters
title: Canada Accuses Indian Diplomats of Criminal Activities
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau accused the Indian government of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada. Canada expelled India’s top diplomat and five others. India denied the allegations.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau accused the Indian government of homicide and extortion intended to silence critics of India living in Canada. Canada expelled India’s top diplomat and five others. India denied the allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wpvi, Via Associated Press
title: New Jersey Transit Train Hits Tree on Track, Killing Train Operator
description: Nearly two dozen people were injured when the light rail train collided with a chunk of tree in South Jersey.
content: Nearly two dozen people were injured when the light rail train collided with a chunk of tree in South Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Harris Rallies in North Carolina
description: The vice president criticized former President Donald J. Trump, calling him “weak and unstable.”
content: The vice president criticized former President Donald J. Trump, calling him “weak and unstable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By NASA
title: NASA Launches Mission to Study Jupiter’s Moon
description: Europa Clipper will study whether Europa, Jupiter’s fourth-largest moon, possesses ingredients and conditions favorable for life.
content: Europa Clipper will study whether Europa, Jupiter’s fourth-largest moon, possesses ingredients and conditions favorable for life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Israel Attacks Tent Camp at Gaza Hospital
description: People worked through smoke and darkness to extinguish fires and look through debris following the deadly attack on Deir al-Balah.
content: People worked through smoke and darkness to extinguish fires and look through debris following the deadly attack on Deir al-Balah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilbert Cruz, Karen Hanley and Claire Hogan
title: 4 Creepy Books to Read This Halloween
description: Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of his personal favorite creepy books to read in October.
content: Gilbert Cruz, editor of The New York Times Book Review, recommends four of his personal favorite creepy books to read in October.
source.name: The New York Times
